steps.title: Welcome
steps.description: This demo walks through creating a complete Tutor Domain ‚Äî from an empty system to a working AI tutor that adapts to each learner.

content.body:
# Create a Tutor Domain

In this walkthrough, you'll see how to set up a complete AI tutoring experience from scratch.

## What you'll build

- **A Domain** ‚Äî the top-level container for your tutor
- **An Identity Spec** ‚Äî defines WHO the tutor is
- **Content Sources** ‚Äî WHAT the tutor teaches
- **A Playbook** ‚Äî ties identity + content + measurement together
- **Onboarding** ‚Äî how new callers are greeted

## Time: ~8 minutes

Use **‚Üê ‚Üí** arrow keys or the buttons below to navigate. Press **?** to ask the AI assistant a question at any point.

steps.reason: Understanding the full setup flow helps you create effective learning domains.
steps.goal: Orient the viewer on what this demo covers

tips.message: Arrow keys navigate, Space toggles autoplay, ? opens AI assistant

aiContext.action: Starting the Create a Tutor Domain demo

steps.title: Find Domains
steps.description: Navigate to the Domains page using the sidebar. Domains are the top-level organizational unit ‚Äî everything in HumanFirst belongs to a domain.
steps.reason: Domains group all related specs, callers, and content together. Each domain represents a distinct learning experience.

steps.title: Create Domain
steps.description: Click 'New Domain' to start creating a new tutoring domain. You'll give it a name, slug, and description.

content.alt: Domains page with New Domain button highlighted

steps.reason: The domain name appears in the UI and reports. The slug is used in URLs and API calls ‚Äî choose something short and descriptive.

tips.message: Domain slugs must be unique, URL-safe, and lowercase (e.g., 'qm-tutor')

aiContext.currentView: Domains listing page with New Domain button

steps.title: Domain Details
steps.description: Fill in the domain details: name ('Quantum Mechanics Tutor'), description, and any initial configuration.
steps.reason: The description helps operators and team members understand what this domain is for. It's also used by the AI assistant for context.

aiContext.action: Filling in domain name, description, and configuration

steps.title: Identity Spec
steps.description: Navigate to Specs and create (or select) an IDENTITY spec. This defines WHO the tutor is ‚Äî personality, teaching style, and boundaries.

content.alt: Specs page filtered to IDENTITY role

steps.reason: Identity specs define WHO the agent is. Every tutor domain needs one. Without an identity spec, the AI has no personality or teaching guidelines.
steps.goal: Set up the tutor's identity and personality

tips.message: Start with the Generic Tutor Identity (TUT-001) and customize from there

aiContext.currentView: Specs page filtered to IDENTITY role
aiContext.action: Selecting an identity spec for the tutor domain

steps.title: Configure Identity
steps.description: The identity spec has parameters that control the tutor's behavior ‚Äî warmth, formality, pacing, and more. These are measured and adapted per-caller.

right.body:
## Key Parameters

- **Warmth**: How friendly vs. professional
- **Formality**: Casual vs. formal tone
- **Pacing**: Fast-moving vs. thorough
- **Exploration**: Open-ended vs. structured

These aren't fixed ‚Äî the pipeline **measures** each caller's preferences and **adapts** the tutor's style over time.

All parameters are fully dynamic. Adding new ones = activating a spec. Zero code changes.

steps.reason: The adaptive parameter system is core to HumanFirst. The tutor doesn't use one style for everyone ‚Äî it learns and adjusts per caller.

aiContext.currentView: Identity spec parameter configuration ‚Äî split view with JSON and explanation
aiContext.action: Reviewing identity spec parameters (warmth, formality, pacing, exploration)

steps.title: Content Sources
steps.description: Navigate to Content Sources to define WHAT the tutor teaches. Each source has a trust level (L0-L5) that controls how the AI uses it.

content.alt: Content Sources page with trust level badges

steps.reason: Trust levels control accuracy requirements. L5 (Verified Fact) content must be quoted exactly. L1 (Community) content can be discussed freely. This matters for regulated training domains like food safety.
steps.goal: Add authoritative content for the tutor to teach

tips.message: For regulated subjects, use trust level L4+ to ensure accurate teaching

aiContext.currentView: Content Sources page with trust level badges
aiContext.action: Adding content sources with trust levels

steps.title: Upload Curriculum
steps.description: Upload a curriculum document (PDF, DOCX, or TXT). The system extracts teaching points and learning objectives automatically.

content.alt: Upload dialog with a sample PDF

steps.reason: The upload flow extracts structured assertions from documents. These become the foundation for what the tutor teaches ‚Äî and what it assesses learners on.

tips.message: Supported formats: PDF, DOCX, TXT. The system extracts teaching points and learning objectives automatically.

aiContext.action: Uploading a curriculum document for assertion extraction

steps.title: Create Playbook
steps.description: Navigate to Playbooks and create one. A playbook ties identity + content + measurement specs together into a complete tutor configuration.
steps.reason: Playbooks are the execution plan. They define which specs run in which order, for which domain. Publishing a playbook makes it 'live' for callers.
steps.goal: Create the execution plan for the tutor

aiContext.action: Creating a new playbook for the tutor domain

steps.title: Playbook Items
steps.description: Add specs to the playbook using the PlaybookBuilder. Drag to reorder. Each item links to a spec and defines whether it's required or optional.
steps.reason: The playbook defines execution order and which specs are required vs. optional. Required specs block activation if missing.

tips.message: At minimum: 1 IDENTITY + 1 CONTENT + personality measurement (PERS-001)

aiContext.currentView: PlaybookBuilder with spec items being configured
aiContext.action: Adding and ordering specs in the playbook

steps.title: Measurement Specs
steps.description: Enable measurement specs to track learner personality and learning style. PERS-001 measures Big Five traits; VARK-001 detects learning modality.

content.alt: Specs page showing EXTRACT role specs

steps.reason: Measurement specs make the tutor adaptive. Without them, every caller gets the same experience. With them, the tutor learns each person's style.
steps.goal: Enable adaptive learning by measuring each caller

tips.message: Activate PERS-001 (personality) and VARK-001 (learning modality) for adaptive tutoring

aiContext.action: Enabling personality and learning style measurement specs

steps.title: Onboarding
steps.description: Configure how new callers are greeted in their first interaction. Set the identity spec for onboarding and define the flow phases.
steps.reason: First impressions matter. Onboarding defines how the tutor introduces itself, what it asks about the learner, and how it sets expectations.

aiContext.action: Configuring the onboarding flow for new callers

steps.title: Review & Activate
steps.description: Before going live, review the domain readiness dashboard. It validates that all required components are present and correctly configured.
steps.reason: The readiness checker catches configuration issues before they affect real callers. Critical checks must pass; recommended checks are advisory.
steps.goal: Validate the domain is ready for callers

tips.message: Critical checks must pass before the domain can accept callers

aiContext.currentView: Domain readiness dashboard with check results
aiContext.action: Reviewing domain readiness checks before activation

steps.title: Test in Simulator
steps.description: Open the Simulator to test the tutor with a real call. The Sim sends calls through the full pipeline ‚Äî everything is live except the phone connection.

content.alt: Sim page with a test conversation

steps.reason: The Simulator is the safest way to verify your tutor works. It runs the full pipeline (measure ‚Üí adapt ‚Üí compose) so you see exactly what callers will experience.

tips.message: The Sim runs the full pipeline ‚Äî personality measurement, adaptation, and prompt composition all happen live

aiContext.action: Testing the tutor with a simulated call

steps.title: Done!
steps.description: Your tutor domain is now live and ready for callers. Here's what to do next.

content.body:
# Tutor Domain Created

You've built a complete AI tutoring experience:

- ‚úÖ **Domain** created and configured
- ‚úÖ **Identity Spec** defines the tutor's personality
- ‚úÖ **Content Sources** provide teaching material
- ‚úÖ **Playbook** ties everything together
- ‚úÖ **Measurement Specs** enable adaptive learning
- ‚úÖ **Onboarding** welcomes new callers
- ‚úÖ **Readiness** checks all passed
- ‚úÖ **Tested** in the Simulator

## Next Steps

1. **Invite callers** ‚Äî use the invite system to bring in real learners
2. **Monitor the pipeline** ‚Äî watch how the tutor adapts to each person
3. **Iterate on specs** ‚Äî refine based on what you observe
4. **Add more content** ‚Äî upload additional curriculum documents

## Related Demos

- *Managing Callers & Progress* (coming soon)
- *Understanding the Analysis Pipeline* (coming soon)
- *Creating Custom Specs* (coming soon)

steps.reason: A well-configured domain is just the start. The real value comes from monitoring, iterating, and expanding.
steps.goal: Summarize what was built and guide next steps
